{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3131506,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-21T22:02:30.160Z","cooked":"

So I’m trying to get the alliance color from the FMS and then using that to choose an autonomous from the smartdashboard. However, I’m getting this error here:
Unhandled exception: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Commands that have been composed may not be added to another composition or scheduled individually!

I’ve never seen this before. I have my code here: Elliot Scher / 2815 Robot 2023 · GitLab

Essentially this is the way my code works:

  1. In Constants.java I create an AutoPath object for each trajectory and add them to a list
  2. Each of these objects creates a ramsetecommand
  3. In an AutoRoutine object which extends sequentialcommandgroup, I get the color alliance we’re on and based on that, loop through either the red or blue autoPath list and use addCommands to add each ramsete command to the sequentialcommandgroup

I’m not sure why this code isn’t working. Has anyone else come across this error before? Thanks!!

Command instances that have been composed (decorated, added to a command group, etc) can’t be composed again or scheduled independently (I’m referring to the composition member – the composition itself can be scheduled or recursively composed). See the docs for more info: Command Compositions — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

In this case, I suspect you’re allocating a static list of commands, and reusing those same instances in multiple compositions. I recommend looking into factory methods or some other way that doesn’t involve reusing preallocated command instances.

If I take those arrays out of my constants file and put them in each autonomous routine would that work better?

The problem is that you’re reusing command instances. Any way you avoid that should work.

Aside, I noticed this:

    public Command getCommand() {
        return m_Command.andThen(
            () -> m_DriveBase.tankDriveVolts(
                0,
                0
            )
        );
    }

A second call to getCommand will fail, because m_Command would get reused. Like I said, do not preallocate and reuse command instances. A possible solution would be creating a new RamseteCommand each invocation of getCommand.
